prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We choose a spectral line setup, with 8 channel averaging, which will lead to a velocity resolution that is (more than) adequate for our needs. The receivers will be tuned such, that for each source the [CII] line falls in the USB, centered between SPW3 and SPW4 (with sufficient overlap between these SPWs). This maximizes the velocity range (+/- 2000 km/s) over which to detect the [CII] line. We note that offsets between Lyman alpha redshifts and [CII] redshifts of ~500 km/s are not uncommon (e.g. Venemans et al. 2015), which is comfortably covered by our setup.

Quasar host galaxies are known to be compact with no angular scales larger than 2", and intrinsic sizes of ~0.5". In this survey proposal, we do not wish to resolve the emission, to avoid possible flux losses, and thus request a compact configuration. The preferred resolution of our observations is 1", but 1.5" or 0.5" are also acceptable. This leads to a configuration requests of C36-1, C36-2, or C36-3.

The goal of this proposal is to detect the [CII] emission line and the underlying FIR continuum emission in a accretion-rate-limited sample of z>5.94 quasars. At the redshifts of our quasar sample, the [CII] line is shifted to band 6. We request an rms noise level in the [CII] of 250 uJy over 300 km/s. At the redshifts probed in this proposal (5.9<z<6.6), this flux corresponds to a 3-sigma limit on the [CII] line luminosity of ~1.0e9 K km/s pc2.
As outlined in the proposal, we note that all the quasars fulfilling the selection criteria of our sample and for which the [CII] line has been reported so far in the literature would result in bright detections at the proposed sensitivity.
We will achieve a continuum sensitivity (over 7.5 GHz) of only 50 uJy (1-sigma). Assuming a modified black body with Tdust=47 K and beta=1.6 (derived from well-sampled SEDs of quasars, e.g. Leipski et al. 2014), this results in a 5-sigma limit on LIR of 5.5e11 L_sun. This is a factor 100 fainter than the brightest quasars detected at z>6, and a factor of 10 fainter than the stacked detection of z>6 quasars by Wang et al. (2008) using MAMBO observations. In summary, we expect the vast majority of quasars of our sample to be detected at high significance.
Our setup is a ~30min Science Goal for each quasar. We stress that these observations constitute an ideal filler program: (1) half hour filler blocks (2) low frequency (band 6) observations (3) our targets reach high elevation and are distributed over large areas of the sky (4) observations are requested in one of the compact configurations (see below).

We choose a spectral line setup, with 8 channel averaging, which will lead to a velocity resolution that is (more than) adequate for our needs. We note that offsets between Lyman alpha redshifts and [CII] redshifts of ~500 km/s are not uncommon (e.g. Venemans et al. 2015), which is comfortably covered by our setup.

We stress that these observations constitute an ideal filler program: (1) half hour filler blocks (2) low frequency (band 6) observations (3) our targets reach high elevation and are distributed over large areas of the sky (4) observations are requested in one of the compact configurations (see below).

We choose a spectral line setup, with 8 channel averaging, which will lead to a velocity resolution that is (more than) adequate for our needs. The receivers will be tuned such, that for each source the [CII] line falls in the USB, centered between SPW3 and SPW4 (with sufficient overlap between these SPWs). This maximizes the velocity range (+/- 2000 km/s) over which to detect the [CII] line. We note that offsets between Lyman alpha redshifts and [CII] redshifts of ~500 km/s are not uncommon (e.g. Venemans et al. 2015), which is comfortably covered by our setup.

Quasar host galaxies are known to be compact with no angular scales larger than 2", and intrinsic sizes of ~0.5". In this survey proposal, we do not wish to resolve the emission, to avoid possible flux losses, and thus request a compact configuration. The preferred resolution of our observations is 1", but 1.5" or 0.5" are also acceptable. This leads to a configuration requests of C36-1, C36-2, or C36-3.

The goal of this proposal is to detect the [CII] emission line and the underlying FIR continuum emission in a accretion-rate-limited sample of z>5.94 quasars. At the redshifts of our quasar sample, the [CII] line is shifted to band 6. We request an rms noise level in the [CII] of 250 uJy over 300 km/s. At the redshifts probed in this proposal (5.9<z<6.6), this flux corresponds to a 3-sigma limit on the [CII] line luminosity of ~1.0e9 K km/s pc2.
As outlined in the proposal, we note that all the quasars fulfilling the selection criteria of our sample and for which the [CII] line has been reported so far in the literature would result in bright detections at the proposed sensitivity.
We will achieve a continuum sensitivity (over 7.5 GHz) of only 50 uJy (1-sigma). Assuming a modified black body with Tdust=47 K and beta=1.6 (derived from well-sampled SEDs of quasars, e.g. Leipski et al. 2014), this results in a 5-sigma limit on LIR of 5.5e11 L_sun. This is a factor 100 fainter than the brightest quasars detected at z>6, and a factor of 10 fainter than the stacked detection of z>6 quasars by Wang et al. (2008) using MAMBO observations. In summary, we expect the vast majority of quasars of our sample to be detected at high significance.

This is a factor 100 fainter than the brightest quasars detected at z>6, and a factor of 10 fainter than the stacked detection of z>6 quasars by Wang et al. (2008) using MAMBO observations. In summary, we expect the vast majority of quasars of our sample to be detected at high significance.
Our setup is a ~30min Science Goal for each quasar. We stress that these observations constitute an ideal filler program: (1) half hour filler blocks (2) low frequency (band 6) observations (3) our targets reach high elevation and are distributed over large areas of the sky (4) observations are requested in one of the compact configurations (see below).

We choose a spectral line setup, with 8 channel averaging, which will lead to a velocity resolution that is (more than) adequate for our needs. The receivers will be tuned such, that for each source the [CII] line falls in the USB, centered between SPW3 and SPW4 (with sufficient overlap between these SPWs). This maximizes the velocity range (+/- 2000 km/s) over which to detect the [CII] line. We note that offsets between Lyman alpha redshifts and [CII] redshifts of ~500 km/s are not uncommon (e.g. Venemans et al. 2015), which is comfortably covered by our setup.

Quasar host galaxies are known to be compact with no angular scales larger than 2", and intrinsic sizes of ~0.5". In this survey proposal, we do not wish to resolve the emission, to avoid possible flux losses, and thus request a compact configuration. The preferred resolution of our observations is 1", but 1.5" or 0.5" are also acceptable. This leads to a configuration requests of C36-1, C36-2, or C36-3.

The goal of this proposal is to detect the [CII] emission line and the underlying FIR continuum emission in a accretion-rate-limited sample of z>5.94 quasars. At the redshifts of our quasar sample, the [CII] line is shifted to band 6. We request an rms noise level in the [CII] of 250 uJy over 300 km/s. At the redshifts probed in this proposal (5.9<z<6.6), this flux corresponds to a 3-sigma limit on the [CII] line luminosity of ~1.0e9 K km/s pc2.
As outlined in the proposal, we note that all the quasars fulfilling the selection criteria of our sample and for which the [CII] line has been reported so far in the literature would result in bright detections at the proposed sensitivity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Optically-selected quasars have been detected well into the epoch of reionization, indicating the existence of supermassive black holes (SMBH) within one Gyr of the Big Bang. FIR continuum and line observations of selected sources have revealed that quasar hosts often show intense star formation and massive, enriched gas reservoirs. We propose to observe an accretion-rate-limited sample (35 quasars total, the majority recently discovered by us using Pan-STARRS1) in [CII] and continuum emission, spanning a factor of ~20 in quasar bolometric luminosity, ~40 in SMBH mass, and ~100 in FIR luminosity. This critical five-fold increase in sample size was simply inconceivable pre-ALMA. We will study the fraction of high-z quasars associated with massive starbursts, will reveal any correlation between SMBH accretion (+ Eddington ratios) and star formation, and will constrain ISM masses. [CII] observations will provide first insights on the host dynamics, feedback, and on cosmic reionization through precise redshift measurements. This first population study of SMBH-galaxy coevolution at the highest accessible redshifts can conveniently be scheduled as time fillers.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
